channel.title: Bloomberg Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Apple Operations Chief to Retire in Major Changing of Guard
item.description: Apple Inc. Chief Operating Officer Jeff Williams is retiring as the company’s longtime No. 2, marking a blockbuster changing of the guard for the iPhone maker.
item.dc:creator: Mark Gurman

media:content.media:description: Jeff Williams, chief operating officer of Apple Inc., speaks to customers at the company's store in Palo Alto, California, US, on Friday, Feb. 2, 2024. Apple Inc.'s first major new product in nine years arrives on Friday as the Vision Pro, a $3,499 mixed-reality headset, goes on sale in the US.

item.title: Apple Supplier Lens Technology to Debut in Hong Kong After $607 Million Float
item.description: Lens Technology Co., a Chinese manufacturer of touch-screen covers for Apple Inc.’s iPhone, will begin trading in Hong Kong on Wednesday after its HK$4.8 billion ($607 million) debut stock offering in the city.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Kelly Li

media:content.media:description: The corporate flag for Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd. (HKEX), right, and the Chinese flag, left, fly outside the Exchange Square complex in Hong Kong, China, on Monday, Sept. 16, 2019. The Hong Kong bourse's unsolicited takeover bid for the London Stock Exchange Group Plc was greeted with a scathing rejection and the exchange suffered a further humiliation when China praised the rebuff as well. Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg

item.title: China’s Got Big Plans for AI — In the Desert
item.description: A Bloomberg investigation finds China is building data centers in the remote Xinjiang region to fuel its AI ambitions — and looking to buy 115,000 Nvidia chips to power them.
item.dc:creator: K Oanh Ha, Yang Yang, Naomi Garyan Ng

media:content.media:description: Yiwu Advanced Computing Cluster Photographer: James Mayger/Bloomberg

item.title: Apple Loses Another AI Exec, Amazon's Prime Day Weakness | Bloomberg Tech 7/8/2025
item.description: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde discusses Apple's latest AI talent loss as a key AI executive leaves for Meta. Plus, Amazon's Prime Day kicks off to a tepid start as retailers and shoppers feel the bite of tariffs. And a conversation with CoreWeave CEO Michael Intrator as they buy Core Scientific in a $9 billion deal. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: OpenAI CEO Altman Looks to Zuckerberg Reunion Amid Poaching Spat
item.description: OpenAI Chief Executive Officer Sam Altman hasn’t yet spoken to Mark Zuckerberg since the Meta Platforms Inc. chief executive officer poached some of OpenAI’s top engineers, but he’s anticipating a meeting at the Sun Valley conference this week and “looking forward to it.”
item.dc:creator: Kelcee Griffis, Edward Ludlow

media:content.media:description: OpenAI CEO Sam Altman speaks to members of the media while arriving at the Sun Valley lodge for the Allen & Company Sun Valley Conference on July 8. Photographer: Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images

item.title: China Wants 115,000 Nvidia Chips to Power Data Centers in the Desert
item.description: Companies want to buy 115,000 banned Nvidia chips to power the country’s AI ambitions.
item.dc:creator: Andy Lin (News), Mackenzie Hawkins, Colum Murphy, James Mayger, Jin Wu, Adrian Leung

item.title: US Sanctions Target North Korean Fake-Tech-Worker Scheme
item.description: The US slapped sanctions on individuals and companies linked to a scheme that involves recruiting North Koreans to pose as American tech workers and help fund Kim Jong Un’s regime.
item.dc:creator: Magdalena Del Valle

media:content.media:description: A North Korean flag flies at the Embassy of North Korea compound in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Saturday, March 20, 2021. Kim Jong Un’s regime cut off diplomatic relations with Malaysia, accusing it of a “super-large hostile act” after its top court ruled a North Korean man can be extradited to the U.S. face money-laundering charges. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: Meta Invests $3.5 Billion in World’s Largest Eye-Wear Maker in AI Glasses Push
item.description: Meta Plaforms Inc. bought a minority stake in the world’s largest eye-wear maker EssilorLuxottica SA, a deal that increases the US tech giant’s financial commitment to the fast-growing smart glasses industry, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Kurt Wagner, Tommaso Ebhardt, Daniele Lepido

media:content.media:description: Ray-Ban Meta smart glasses on display in the window of a Ray Ban store in London, UK, on Friday, July 19, 2024. The luxury sector faces more scrutiny when companies report as feeble demand pressures margins.

item.title: Musk's Political Ambitions, CoreWeave's Big Purchase | Bloomberg Tech 7/7/2025
item.description: Bloomberg’s Caroline Hyde and Ed Ludlow discuss Elon Musk's political aspirations as he forms the "America Party." Plus, President Donald Trump fires more tariff warnings as countries race to negotiate ahead of the Wednesday deadline. And CoreWeave is set to buy Core Scientific in a $9 billion deal. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Rubio Impostor Used AI, Signal to Contact Foreign Officials
item.description: Someone pretending to be Secretary of State Marco Rubio used AI-generated voice technology and a fake Signal account to contact foreign officials and at least one member of Congress, the latest case of impostors mimicking senior US officials.
item.dc:creator: Nick Wadhams

media:content.media:description: US Secretary of State Marco Rubio

item.title: Intel Cuts Over 500 Jobs in Oregon as Part of Layoff Plan
item.description: Intel Corp. is cutting more than 500 positions in Oregon as part of a layoff plan that’s ultimately expected to affect roughly 20% of the chipmaker’s staff.
item.dc:creator: Ian King

media:content.media:description: The Intel headquarters in Santa Clara, California.

item.title: Amazon Faces Scrutiny as Canada’s Competition Watchdog Deepens Probe
item.description: Canada’s competition watchdog secured a court order to help its investigation into whether Amazon.com Inc. is abusing its dominant retail position in the market.
item.dc:creator: Chaimae Chouiekh

media:content.media:description: Packages are scanned on a conveyor belt at an Amazon.com Inc. fulfilment center. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

item.title: Mistral in Talks With MGX, Others to Raise Up to $1 Billion
item.description: French artificial intelligence startup Mistral AI is in talks to raise as much as $1 billion in equity from several investors including Abu Dhabi fund MGX, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Berthelot, Dinesh Nair, Mark Bergen

media:content.media:description: The Mistral AI website.

item.title: Waymo Begins Offering Teen Accounts, Starting in Metro Phoenix
item.description: Alphabet Inc.’s Waymo is launching a new account type that lets teenagers hail a robotaxi and ride alone, expanding its rider base while continuing to test its service in more US cities.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Lung

media:content.media:description: A Waymo autonomous taxi in San Francisco, California, US, on Thursday Aug. 10, 2023. California regulators are poised to decide whether two rival robotaxi services can provide around-the-clock rides throughout San Francisco, despite escalating fears about recurring incidents that have caused the driverless vehicles to block traffic or imperil public safety, reported the AP.

item.title: Waymo Tests Bring NYC One Step Closer to Autonomous Taxis
item.description: Waymo’s first self-driving taxis arrived in New York City this week to begin collecting data with a human behind the wheel as the company seeks a permit for autonomous testing.
item.dc:creator: Jade Thomas

media:content.media:description: Waymo LLC signage is displayed on the door of a Chrysler Pacifica autonomous vehicle in Chandler, Arizona, U.S., on Monday, July 30, 2018. The Google offshoot is tinkering with pricing and finalizing its business model for autonomous vehicles, which includes a new effort to boost public transit. Photographer: Caitlin O'Hara/Bloomberg

item.title: Lyft Launches in Puerto Rico in Latest Geographical Expansion
item.description: Lyft Inc. on Tuesday launched its rideshare service in Puerto Rico as the next step in an expansion across North America and Europe.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Lung

media:content.media:description: Lyft signage on a vehicle in New York, US, on Thursday, Aug. 8, 2024. In the past two weeks, Uber Technologies Inc., DoorDash Inc., Instacart, Grubhub parent Just Eat Takeaway, and Deliveroo Plc have all delivered upbeat earnings reports, suggesting that ride-sharing and food delivery are both entrenched habits baked into consumer's budgets, and serving as a counterpoint to fears that US consumer spending is softening across the board.

item.title: Uber Traders Shrug Off Robotaxi Risks as Stock Powers to Record
item.description: Uber Technologies Inc. investors are brushing aside potential threats from self-driving competition to bet that the company has plenty of room to expand in the near term.
item.dc:creator: Carmen Reinicke

item.title: Tether Holds an $8 Billion Pile of Gold in a Secret Swiss Vault
item.description: Tether Holdings SA, the issuer of the world’s largest stablecoin, has its own vault in Switzerland to hold an $8 billion stockpile of gold, with an eye to growing those stores.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ryan

media:content.media:description: Paolo Ardoino, chief executive officer of Tether Holdings Ltd

item.title: OpenAI, Microsoft Back New Academy to Bring AI Into Classrooms
item.description: OpenAI, Microsoft Corp. and Anthropic are partnering with one of the largest teachers unions in the US to establish a new training center to help educators use artificial intelligence tools in classrooms across the country.
item.dc:creator: Brunella Tipismana Urbano

media:content.media:description: A high school student works on a school assignment in Tiskilwa, Illinois.

item.title: Amazon Prime Day Spending Down 14% in Early Hours From 2024
item.description: Amazon.com Inc.’s Prime Day sales fell almost 14% in the first four hours of the event compared with the start of last year’s sale, according to Momentum Commerce, which manages 50 brands in a variety of product categories.
item.dc:creator: Spencer Soper

media:content.media:description: A worker prepares orders at the Amazon.com Inc. fulfillment centre in Dartford, UK.

item.title: Cathie Wood Bats Away Latest Musk Controversy After Tesla Slide
item.description: Cathie Wood, a longtime backer of Elon Musk, is standing by the Tesla Inc. chief executive after a turbulent start to the week that saw shares in the electric vehicle-maker plunge after the billionaire businessman announced he’s forming a new political party.
item.dc:creator: Isabelle Lee, Jonathan Ferro, Lisa Abramowicz

media:content.media:description: Cathie Wood, chief executive officer of Ark Investment Management LLC, during a Bloomberg Television interview in London, UK, on Monday, May 19, 2025. We expect real GDP in the US to accelerate, Wood said.

item.title: Three Men Guilty for Wagner Group Backed Arson Attack in London
item.description: A London jury found three men guilty for carrying out a Russia backed arson attack on a London warehouse of a firm that supplied goods, including Starlink satellite equipment, to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Upmanyu Trivedi

media:content.media:description: The Central Criminal Court in London.

item.title: Trump Media Furthers Push Into Crypto With Third ETF Filing
item.description: Trump Media & Technology Group Corp. is plowing deeper into the cryptocurrencies space with a new filing for an exchange-traded fund that would hold a number of digital assets including Bitcoin, Ether, Solana and others.
item.dc:creator: Vildana Hajric

item.title: X Says India Government Ordered Blocking Reuters’ Accounts
item.description: X raised serious concerns about India’s media laws after the government ordered it to block thousands of accounts, including from international media like Reuters, according to a statement issued by their global governance team.
item.dc:creator: Swati Gupta

media:content.media:description: The X app.

item.title: SoFi to Give Clients Access to OpenAI, SpaceX Through New Funds
item.description: SoFi Technologies Inc. said it’s adding new private-markets funds that will allow retail clients to invest in closely held companies including SpaceX, OpenAI and Epic Games.
item.dc:creator: Jayna Rohslau

media:content.media:description: The logo for Social Finance (SoFi) on a laptop computer arranged in the Brooklyn borough of New York, U.S., on Friday, March 26, 2021. Social Finance Inc., the online lender that earlier this year reached a deal to go public, plans to offer its retail customers the ability to invest in initial public offerings.

item.title: Vodacom, Remgro Head Toward $743 Million Fiber-Deal Approval
item.description: South Africa’s anti-trust watchdog will not oppose the 13.2 billion rand ($743 million) fiber transaction between Vodacom Group Ltd. and Remgro Ltd. at the Competition Appeal Court, increasing chances that the deal will go ahead.
item.dc:creator: Loni Prinsloo

media:content.media:description: Fiber optic cables. Photographer: Alessia Pierdomenico/Bloomberg

item.title: Chipmaker SiPearl Raises €130 Million in EU Sovereign AI Push
item.description: European Union-backed chipmaker SiPearl has raised €130 million ($152 million) from investors including Taiwan’s Cathay Venture, as Europe pushes for technological sovereignty.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Berthelot

media:content.media:description: A silicon wafer.

item.title: M&S Says April Cyberattack Caused by Third-Party Impersonation
item.description: The cyberattack that derailed Marks and Spencer Group Plc’s operations for weeks was the result of a “sophisticated impersonation” of one of the retailer’s third-party users, according to Chairman Archie Norman.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Creery

media:content.media:description: The entrance to a Marks & Spencer Group Plc store in London.

item.title: EV Racing Struggles as Climate Action Falls on Priority List
item.description: Welcome to Tech In Depth, our daily newsletter about the business of tech from Bloomberg’s journalists around the world. Today, Luz Ding looks at Formula E’s fortunes in a climate of diminishing interest in sustainability and environmental awareness. Also, sign up for Bloomberg's Business of Sports newsletter for the context you need on the collision of power, money and sports.
item.dc:creator: Luz Ding

media:content.media:description: Formula E racing in Tokyo.

item.title: Deadly Telecom Blaze Shuts Cairo Stock Trading and Hits Internet
item.description: A blaze at a key downtown Cairo telephone exchange left at least four people dead and another 27 injured, cutting off network services and forcing the local stock exchange to cancel Tuesday’s trading session.
item.dc:creator: Tarek El-Tablawy

media:content.media:description: Firefighters tackle a blaze at a a key telephone exchange in Cairo on July 8. Photographer: Amr Nabil/AP Photo
